passages.title: Medication Guidelines
passages.content: When prescribing antibiotics, healthcare professionals must consider several factors. The patient's medical history, current medications, and any known allergies are crucial. Penicillin-based antibiotics are effective against many bacterial infections but should not be prescribed to patients with penicillin allergies. The standard dosage for adults is typically 500mg three times daily, taken with food to reduce stomach irritation. Patients should complete the full course even if symptoms improve early.

passages.title: Patient Discharge Instructions
passages.content: Following your surgical procedure, it is important to monitor the surgical site for signs of infection. These include increased redness, swelling, warmth, or discharge. Take your prescribed pain medication as directed, typically every 4-6 hours as needed. Avoid heavy lifting for at least two weeks. Your follow-up appointment is scheduled for April 15, 2024. If you experience severe pain, fever above 38.5°C, or excessive bleeding, contact the emergency department immediately.

audio_files.title: Patient Consultation
audio_files.transcript: Doctor: Good morning, Mrs. Johnson. What brings you in today? Patient: I've been having severe headaches for the past two weeks. They're getting worse, especially in the mornings. Doctor: Can you rate the pain on a scale of 1 to 10? Patient: It's about an 8 out of 10. Doctor: Are you taking any current medications? Patient: Just my blood pressure medication, Lisinopril. Doctor: I'm going to prescribe Sumatriptan for the headaches. Take one tablet when you feel a headache coming on.

questions.question: How long has the patient been experiencing headaches?
What is the patient's pain level on a scale of 1-10?
What medication is the patient currently taking?
What medication did the doctor prescribe for the headaches?
When are the headaches typically worse?

passages.title: Clinical Research Study
passages.content: A recent randomized controlled trial examined the effectiveness of a new diabetes management program. The study included 500 participants with Type 2 diabetes over 12 months. Participants were randomly assigned to either the intervention group (new program) or control group (standard care). The intervention group showed a 1.2% reduction in HbA1c levels compared to 0.3% in the control group. Additionally, 78% of intervention participants achieved target glucose levels versus 45% in the control group. The program included weekly educational sessions, peer support groups, and mobile app monitoring.

questions.question: How many participants were included in the study?
What was the HbA1c reduction in the intervention group?
What percentage of intervention participants achieved target glucose levels?

audio_files.transcript: Pharmacist: Good afternoon, Mr. Davies. I'm reviewing your medications today. You're currently on three medications: Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes, Lisinopril 10mg once daily for blood pressure, and Atorvastatin 20mg at bedtime for cholesterol. Have you experienced any side effects? Patient: The Metformin sometimes upsets my stomach. Pharmacist: That's common. Try taking it with meals. Your blood pressure is well controlled, and your recent cholesterol levels look good. Continue all medications as prescribed.
